textfield.text: Exploring English Language Networks with GooGle N-Grams
a consecutive usage of N words (directed!)

LI.FONT: a consecutive usage of N words (directed!)

textfield.text: Each N-Gram is weighted by the frequency of which it appears in the data set

LI.FONT: Each N-Gram is weighted by the frequency of which it appears in the data set
we focused solely on 2-Grams

textfield.text: Analyzed a subset of 10 of them!

LI.FONT: Analyzed a subset of 10 of them!

textfield.text: Implemented programs to filter and validate entries

LI.FONT: Implemented programs to filter and validate entries

textfield.text: reduced overall data size by 75 percent

LI.FONT: reduced overall data size by 75 percent

textfield.text: power law distribution indicates a scale free network

LI.FONT: power law distribution indicates a scale free network
Distinct "double power-law"

textfield.text: observed by other groups in various networks

LI.FONT: observed by other groups in various networks

textfield.text: Shows lack of low degree nodes or abundance of hubs

LI.FONT: Shows lack of low degree nodes or abundance of hubs
Negative slope shows Disassortativity.
This is an expected result

textfield.text: The number of nodes and links in the network nearly doubles within the last century

LI.FONT: The number of nodes and links in the network nearly doubles within the last century

textfield.text: Randomly sampling provides an acceptable approximation to most local network topological parameters

P.FONT: Randomly sampling provides an acceptable approximation to most local network topological parameters

textfield.text: However, for some global measures it is best to sample as much data as possible

P.FONT: However, for some global measures it is best to sample as much data as possible

textfield.text: The Boost Graph Library was implemented to write algorithims that could handle the large data sets

P.FONT: The Boost Graph Library was implemented to write algorithims that could handle the large data sets

textfield.text: a More interesting question, how Do weights scale with degree?

LI.FONT: a More interesting question, how Do weights scale with degree?

textfield.text: Average Clustering as a function of Degree

P.FONT: Average Clustering as a function of Degree

textfield.text: we depend on some pairs of words heavily but almost never use some...

LI.FONT: we depend on some pairs of words heavily but almost never use some...

textfield.text: ...The strength of a node is strictly a linear function of its degree, indicates absence of correlations between the weight of edges and the degree of nodes

P.FONT: ...The strength of a node is strictly a linear function of its degree,
indicates absence of correlations between the weight of edges and the degree of nodes

textfield.text: More than an order of magnitude decrease in the average clustering coefficient from the low connectivity words to the highest

LI.FONT: More than an order of magnitude decrease in the average clustering coefficient from the low connectivity words to the highest

textfield.text: Words that are connected through a hub are less likely to be neighbors.

LI.FONT: Words that are connected through a hub are less likely to be neighbors.

textfield.text: Further emphasizes the importance of articles, prepositions, and simple verbs in tying our sentences together

LI.FONT: Further emphasizes the importance of articles, prepositions, and simple verbs in tying our sentences together

textfield.text:
"this is getting very small"
"...And so proceed ad infinitum."
tail degree exponent of 2.64 puts this in "Ultra small world" regime

LI.FONT: tail degree exponent of 2.64 puts this in "Ultra small world" regime

textfield.text: The frequency of 2-grams (weight of link between the words) follows a power law (zipf's Law)

LI.FONT: The frequency of 2-grams (weight of link between the words) follows a power law (zipf's Law)

textfield.text: N-grams are a measure of syntax or the structure of sentences

LI.FONT: N-grams are a measure of syntax or the structure of sentences

textfield.text: Articles, conjunctions, and prepositions are the mortar that holds our sentences together, but often have verbs, adjectives and nouns interposed

LI.FONT: Articles, conjunctions, and prepositions are the mortar that holds our sentences together, but often have verbs, adjectives and nouns interposed

textfield.text: Note that a relatively low degree word is connected to very high degree hubs

LI.FONT: Note that a relatively low degree word is connected to very high degree hubs

textfield.text: Double power law degree exponents very stable.

LI.FONT: Double power law degree exponents very stable.

textfield.text: Normalization constant however is increasing with time, reflecting more overall usage of English text, as expected.

LI.FONT: Normalization constant however is increasing with time, reflecting more overall usage of English text, as expected.

textfield.text: google's Corpus is growing, quite substantially.

P.FONT: google's Corpus is growing, quite substantially.

textfield.text: Nearly constant links/node supports that new 2-grams are due mainly to the introduction of new nodes, not internal link creation.

LI.FONT: Nearly constant links/node supports that new 2-grams are due mainly to the introduction of new nodes, not internal link creation.

textfield.text: the information content of our language comes from lower-degree words between the hubs

LI.FONT: the information content of our language comes from lower-degree words between the hubs

LI.FONT: C++ Standard Template Library for data processing and large Graph analysis

LI.FONT: Cytoscape and Network workbench for Network visualization and analysis
EasyPlot for plotting and fitting

textfield.text: Exponential cutoff is a poor fit

LI.FONT: Exponential cutoff is a poor fit

textfield.text: English 2-Grams Follow Zipf's Law (power law weight Dist)

LI.FONT: English 2-Grams Follow Zipf's Law (power law weight Dist)

textfield.text: English words Are arranged into a disassortative, scale free network with weighted edges.

LI.FONT: English words Are arranged into a disassortative, scale free network with weighted edges.

textfield.text: Google N-Gram data shows a linear increase of english words and 2-grams over time.

LI.FONT: Google N-Gram data shows a linear increase of english words and 2-grams over time.

textfield.text: The degree and weight distributions of words and links follow a double power law that is stable over the 20th century

LI.FONT: The degree and weight distributions of words and links follow a double power law that is stable over the 20th century

textfield.text: There is evidence of a lack of internal link creation (Most new links come from initial connectivity of new nodes)

LI.FONT: There is evidence of a lack of internal link creation (Most new links come from initial connectivity of new nodes)

textfield.text: The weight of the edge shows no correlation to the degree of the vertex

LI.FONT: The weight of the edge shows no correlation to the degree of the vertex
